- Offer in Compromise (OIC) Coordinator detailing procedures for OIC. (

Planning and Special Programs (PSP)
Theodore D Setzer
Table of Contents
Examination Features and Programs 4.1.8
) Purpose: This IRM section provides guidance and instruction on the tion and assignment of returns with international issues. Scope and (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are WEIIC Planning and Specialty Program (PSP) employees. (
) Policy Owner: LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy and Governance in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration organization. (
) Program Owner: WEIIC is responsible for administering this program. (

) Program Goals: The goals of the WEIIC PSP area align with the LB&I Strategic Goals to apply the tax laws with integrity and fairness through a highly skilled and satisﬁed workforce, in an environment of inclusion where each employee can make a maximum contribution to the mission of the (

) WEIIC PSP is responsible for classiﬁcation and assignment of cases of U.S. citizens living and/or working abroad or in a U.S. Territory, U.S. citizens or resident aliens who hold income producing assets in a foreign country or the foreign earned income exclusion or foreign tax credit, and permanent residents and non-resident aliens who have a U.S. ﬁling requirement. This includes reporting and payment requirements under Chapter
(Withholding Tax on Nonresident Aliens and Foreign Corporations) and Chapter
(Taxes Enforce Reporting on Certain Foreign Accounts) of the Internal Revenue (

) WEIIC PSP area comprised of four program areas, each with different goals and responsibilities, as follows: a. WEIIC Support b. WEIIC Classiﬁcation c. WEIIC Identiﬁcation d. WEIIC Claims and Referrals Processing (
) The development, implementation and oversight of WEIIC PSP procedures the prerogative of the WEIIC director. (

) WEIIC PSP employees and managers should be familiar with and use the amination procedures and information contained in this IRM and be aware of the applicable procedures in other examination IRM chapters, as cited or linked.
Purpose: This IRM section provides guidance and instruction on the classiﬁca- tion and assignment of returns with international issues.
Policy Owner: LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy and Governance office in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration organization.
Program Effectiveness: The efficiency of the case procedures is measured through combined business results of the teams that make up the WEIIC
4.1 Planning and Special
The following is a list of frequently used acronyms in this program:
RA Revenue Agent TCO Tax Compliance Officer TE Tax Examiner WEIIC Withholding Exchange and International Individual Compliance (

) In selecting returns for examination, consider the objectives of the enforcement program. Select returns that contain signiﬁcant international issues which: a. Are potentially non-compliant, or report high-risk tax positions. b. Warrant examination to approve compliance and enhance voluntary pliance. (

) Generally, returns received for classiﬁcation for international potential will already been classiﬁed for domestic issues. The international issue team generally will not screen returns for domestic issues. (

) Returns accepted as ﬁled for international features during centralized cation that have not been previously classiﬁed for domestic issues will be routed through regular classiﬁcation at the campus. (

) Returns selected for international features will be routed to the PSP manager in the area office. These returns will be ﬁled in central ﬁles, suspense ﬁles, or assigned to groups following area procedures. (
) Returns identiﬁed as part of an LB&I large corporate compliance during classiﬁcation are transferred by the classiﬁer to the appropriate LB&I practice area. (
) International classiﬁers separate returns into six categories: a. Domestic issues not classiﬁed—selected for international
Domestic issues not classiﬁed—selected for
Examination Features and Programs 4.1.8 page
The following factors must be considered when classifying these returns:

Is the income from all foreign sources reported on the U.S. income tax return? Has the taxpayer used the proper exchange rate for converting the foreign income? Is the taxpayer an employee or contractor of the U.S. government? Is there a Form
, Foreign Tax Credit, attached to the return? If Form

is attached to the return, determine if the credit claimed is at the treaty rate or at the foreign country’s statutory rate. A citizen or resident claiming the treaty beneﬁt from a foreign country is limited to treaty rate as a foreign tax credit or deduction on the tax return. A tax credit is allowed only to the extent the foreign income taxes are mately both owed and remitted to the foreign country. See Treas. Reg.
(b) and
(08-04-2022) Offer in Compromise (OIC) Coordinator

mise (AOIC) system. a. AOIC access is requested using Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS). See Bears intranet site at gov/home/Index. b. The PSP coordinator will monitor the area OIC-doubt as to liability (DATL) inventory using AOIC. c. The coordinator will update AOIC with case assignment information case updates. d. PSP coordinators should send reminders to the ﬁeld examiners for DATL cases with less than

months remaining on the Tax Increase prevention Reconciliation Act (TIPRA) statute. e. AOIC is the official record-keeping system for OIC-DATL cases. Note: The coordinator should look to AOIC for the offer statute date viously referenced as the TIPRA date) rather than to the ASED AIMS. f. The coordinator will contact the taxpayer/POA for perfection of OIC or quest additional documentation, as needed. g. The coordinator should research IDRS for all tax periods identiﬁed on OIC.
Planning and Special h. If the OIC DATL is based on an exam assessment (TC
) the PSP ordinator will need to order the administrative ﬁle and establish the offer on AIMS. i. OIC cases will have project code
and source code
and Audit In- formation Management System (AIMS) freeze code
Note: The AIMS freeze code prevents the group from updating the case to a status code other than status
This assists in preventing these cases from bypassing Technical Services. j. Determine statutes for assessment. See IRM

Offer in promise - Doubt as to Liability (OIC-DATL) Exam Statute Controls, Note: OIC-DATL cases should contain a statute date that is two years from the IRS received date (generally, the earliest date stamped Form
-L) The statute should also carry an “R” as part of the statute date, e.g. (
R) to assist in identifying the TIPRA statute k. Review the AOIC “Remarks” section to determine if the TC
has been manually input. If so add that information to the case ﬁle (history sheet) that Technical Services will have that information. Note: Manual input of a TC
will require manual input of a TC
X closing code at the conclusion of the examination. l. Please refer to IRM

Exam Offer-In-Compromise, for ﬁeld exam guid- ance and procedures. m. All OIC-DATL cases designated to LB&I should be routed to WEIIC PSP. The WEIIC PSP OIC coordinator will be responsible for establishing all LB&I cases on AIMS prior to assignment to a Territory. The Coordinator responsible for coordinating the assignment of OIC DATL cases to ries within LB&I WEIIC and within LB&I Domestic operations. (

) After Technical Services review is complete, OIC-DATL offer will be closed on AOIC or, if the determination is appealed, updated to Appeals by Technical Services. a. Comparison of AOIC offer information with the AIMS status for the offer case will assist the coordinator with ﬁnding offers where follow-up with Technical Services or a ﬁeld group is required. b. Closing an offer case on AIMS is not closing an offer. An offer will in open status until AOIC is updated to closed status.

All OIC-DATL cases designated to LB&I should be routed to WEIIC PSP. The WEIIC PSP OIC coordinator will be responsible for establishing all LB&I cases on AIMS prior to assignment to a Territory. The Coordinator is responsible for coordinating the assignment of OIC DATL cases to territo- ries within LB&I WEIIC and within LB&I Domestic operations.
